flow.descriptionCdata:
ca82f6ae-579a-410a-93d2-d48ad52eabac.39a0b07d-2230-4bc2-92f9-1172812e79e1.description=
This operation is used to send a smtp email.
 
Inputs\:
    hostname - The hostname or ip address of the smtp server.
    port - The port smtp service is listening.
    from - From email address.
    to - A delimiter separated list of email address(es) or recipients.
    cc - A delimiter separated list of email address(es) or recipients, to be placed in the CC.
    bcc - A delimiter separated list of email address(es) or recipients, to be placed in the BCC.
    subject - The email subject. If a subject spans on multiple lines, it is formatted to a single one.
    body - The body of the email.
    htmlEmail - The value should be true if the email is in rich text/html format. The value should be false if the email is in plain text format.
Valid values\: true, false. 
Default value\: true. 
    readReceipt - The value should be true if read receipt is required, else false. 
Valid values\: true, false. 
Default value\: false. 
    attachments - A delimiter separated list of files to attach (must be full path).
    username - If SMTP authentication is needed, the username to send.
    password - If SMTP authentication is needed, the password to use.
    characterSet - The character set encoding for the entire email which includes subject, body, attached file name and the attached file. 
Valid values\: UTF-8, UTF-16, UTF-32, EUC-JP, ISO-2022-JP, Shift_JIS, Windows-31J.
Default value\: UTF-8.
    contentTransferEncoding - The content transfer encoding scheme (such as 7bit, 8bit, base64, quoted-printable etc) for the entire email which includes subject, body, attached file name and the attached file. 
Valid values\: quoted-printable, base64, 7bit, 8bit, binary, x-token.
Default value\: quoted-printable (or Q Encoding).
    delimiter - A delimiter to separate the email recipients and the attachments.
Default value\: ','
 
Responses\:
    success - Successfully sent the email.
    failure - Failed to send the email.

Note\:
1. For special characters (East Asian, right-to-left languages, etc.) you must install the support files on your local machine.
2. For doing this on Windows go to Control Panel -> Regional and Language Options -> Language and check the options at Supplemental language support.
ca82f6ae-579a-410a-93d2-d48ad52eabac.53d9d09c-82b3-408b-afc2-82d6a7af8822.description=
This operation takes a reference to a XML (in the form of a String) and a specified XPath Query is run against the XML. This returns the results in a form of a delimited list. 
The World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) organization provides the XPath specification (http\://www.w3.org).

Inputs\:
    xml - The XML in the form of a String.
    xpathQuery - The XPath Query that is wanted to be run. See the examples in Notes section below.
    delimiter- The delimiter used to separate values in the returnResult list. 
Default value\: ','.

Results\:
    returnResult - This is the primary output. Contains the results in a form of a delimited list. If multiple XPaths are defined then this will add the delimiter between each value. There is no final delimiter.

Responses\:
    success - The operation completed as stated in the description.
    failure - The operation completed unsuccessfully.

Notes\:
1. The XPath Query can be specified as a single query in a format similiar to the following\:
/employees/employee[@id\="3"]/*[name()\="name" or name()\="jobDescription" or name()\="salary" or name()\="managerId"]/text()

This would return the following results\:
Goofy,tester,$50,1

2. If more than one XPath query needs to be specified, populate xpathQuery using the XPath concat function. Here is a sample of a xpathQuery value using XPath concat function\:
concat(/employees/employee[@id\="2"]/name/text(),',',/employees/employee[@id\="2"]/jobDescription/text(),',',/employees/employee[@id\="2"]/managerId/text(),',',/employees/employee[@id\="2"]/salary/text())

The output using the concat xpathQuery input would return the following results\:
Donald Duck,Lead Coder,1,$50

The examples above use the following XML string value\:


  
    Mickey Mouse
    Chief
    $100
    
  
  
    Donald Duck
    Lead Coder
    $50
    1
  
  
    Goofy
    tester
    $50
    1
  
  
    Pluto
    Coder - grade 1
    $25
    2
ca82f6ae-579a-410a-93d2-d48ad52eabac.8fb4ccdb-8e4a-45d1-8305-fc9b6ff2ce06.description=
This operation takes a reference to a XML (in the form of a String) and a specified XPath Query is run against the XML. This returns the results in a form of a delimited list. 
The World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) organization provides the XPath specification (http\://www.w3.org).

Inputs\:
    xml - The XML in the form of a String.
    xpathQuery - The XPath Query that is wanted to be run. See the examples in Notes section below.
    delimiter- The delimiter used to separate values in the returnResult list. 
Default value\: ','.

Results\:
    returnResult - This is the primary output. Contains the results in a form of a delimited list. If multiple XPaths are defined then this will add the delimiter between each value. There is no final delimiter.

Responses\:
    success - The operation completed as stated in the description.
    failure - The operation completed unsuccessfully.

Notes\:
1. The XPath Query can be specified as a single query in a format similiar to the following\:
/employees/employee[@id\="3"]/*[name()\="name" or name()\="jobDescription" or name()\="salary" or name()\="managerId"]/text()

This would return the following results\:
Goofy,tester,$50,1

2. If more than one XPath query needs to be specified, populate xpathQuery using the XPath concat function. Here is a sample of a xpathQuery value using XPath concat function\:
concat(/employees/employee[@id\="2"]/name/text(),',',/employees/employee[@id\="2"]/jobDescription/text(),',',/employees/employee[@id\="2"]/managerId/text(),',',/employees/employee[@id\="2"]/salary/text())

The output using the concat xpathQuery input would return the following results\:
Donald Duck,Lead Coder,1,$50

The examples above use the following XML string value\:


  
    Mickey Mouse
    Chief
    $100
    
  
  
    Donald Duck
    Lead Coder
    $50
    1
  
  
    Goofy
    tester
    $50
    1
  
  
    Pluto
    Coder - grade 1
    $25
    2
ca82f6ae-579a-410a-93d2-d48ad52eabac.9b40b625-d69b-4dcc-9de4-a2deca30fa47.description=
This operation iterates through a list of values. It is not recommended to modify the value of the "list" and "separator" inputs during the iteration process.

Inputs\:
    list - The list to iterate through.
    separator - A delimiter separating the list elements.
Default value\: ‘,’ (comma) 

Results\:
    resultString - The current list element (if the response is "has more").

Responses\:
    has more - Another value was found in the list and it has been returned.
    no more - The iterator has gone through the entire list. This response is returned once per list iteration.  A subsequent call to the “List iterator” operation restarts the list iteration process.
    failure - The operation completed unsuccessfully.

Note\:
1. The position of the iterator in the list is tracked by each step's unique identifier. Therefore you can simultaneously iterate through the same list from multiple steps.
ca82f6ae-579a-410a-93d2-d48ad52eabac.b9263ba4-34a1-4807-8ab7-2029a518ea69.prompt=Enter your TOSCA XML String ca82f6ae-579a-410a-93d2-d48ad52eabac.c538cff9-63cf-4089-b137-5c3d1475b39b.description=
Removes "eve\:" and "t\:" namespace from a given Tosca XML cloud infrastructure topology.

Inputs\:
    (required)
    infrastructureTopology - string of a cloud infrastructure in Tosca XML.

Results\:
    modifiedXml (primary) - Given topology of Tosca XML without namespace information.

Responses\:
    success - The flow completed as stated in the description.
    failure - The flow completed unsuccessfully.
